settings.instructions:
Overview

This is the INL1Quiz for the Hash Functions lectures. You must get 100% to pass the course. You can retake it. I recommend that you attempt it before the corresponding lecture and then retake it again afterwards.

Grading

If you fail, you will have to go study a bit more and complement your answers. There is a one hour cool-down between attempts. You must have 100% correct answers to pass. Questions will not give partial credit, you get either full score or none.

I suggest that you write down a short motivation for each answer, such that you can review them for the next attempt.

There is no deadline. (Well, the deadline is when you want to get the grade. When all INL1 assignments have a passing grade in Canvas, they'll be automatically transferred to LADOK. This is done once a week, then there might be a few days delay since one of us will have to see the email notification and go certify the results---i.e. click OK---manually in LADOK.)

choices.item_body: Hash functions provide a deterministic transformation from input data to a fixed-size output.
Cryptographic hash functions are designed to be easily invertible so that the original input can be recovered from the output.
Hash functions are widely used to verify data integrity by comparing a computed hash with a known value.
One common use of hash functions is to securely store passwords by hashing them before saving in a database.
Collision resistance means that it is computationally infeasible for two different inputs to produce the same hash output.
Collision resistance means that it is computationally infeasible to find two different inputs that produce the same hash output.
Hash functions can be used for encrypting sensitive data, ensuring that an attacker cannot read it.

Hash functions can be used to link blocks together into a secure the chain. If an adversary wants to change one block, all the following hashes must be recomputed---which will change the hash of the block at the tip of the chain, allowing detection.
Digital signature schemes often rely on hash functions to create a digest of the message before signing.
Hash functions can be used to generate unique identifiers for large files, making it easier to detect duplicates.
A challenge in designing hash functions is that they must be slow to compute in order to resist brute-force attacks.

entry.title: MACs
entry.item_body: What does MAC stand for in cryptographic contexts?

choices.item_body: Message Authentication Code
Media Access Control
Multiple Access Channel
Message Authorization Component

entry.title: MACs
entry.item_body: What is the purpose of a MAC?

choices.item_body: To encrypt messages.
To verify the authenticity and integrity of a message.
To generate public and private keys.
To be a part of establishing a secure communication channel.
MACs are designed to be computationally efficient to generate and verify, making them suitable for real-time applications.
An attacker with access to several valid message-MAC pairs can easily compute a valid MAC for a new message.
The security of a MAC depends on the secrecy of the shared key, not on keeping the algorithm itself secret.
Cryptographic hash functions and MACs have identical security goals since both focus solely on collision resistance.
Although many MACs (like HMAC) are based on hash functions, they add the use of a secret key to provide unforgeability.
MACs produce a fixed-size output regardless of the length of the input message.
A valid MAC guarantees that a message has not been altered and that it was created by someone with knowledge of the secret key.
A valid MAC guarantees that a message has not been altered and that it is delivered by a sender with knowledge of the secret key.
Any alteration to a message will result in a MAC that does not match the original, thus detecting tampering.

entry.title: Hash functions
entry.item_body: Proof-of-work (PoW) and block chains relate to hash functions. Check all statements that are true.

choices.item_body: A typical PoW puzzle is to find a nonce n such that H(block || n) satisfies some condition (e.g., the hash is smaller than a target).
This kind of PoW puzzle is essentially a preimage-style search problem: find an input whose hash output lies in a specified set.
PoW fundamentally requires finding collisions in the hash function (two different inputs with the same hash).
Hash chaining makes tampering detectable because changing one block changes its hash and thus changes all following links.

entry.title: Hash functions
entry.item_body: Assume an ideal hash function with n-bit output. Recall: "k-bit security" means about 2^k operations to break. Check all statements that are true.

choices.item_body: To get about 128-bit security against preimage attacks, we need roughly n >= 128 (because brute force is about 2^n).
To get about 128-bit security against collision attacks, we need roughly n >= 256 (because generic collision search costs about 2^{n/2}).
If n = 128, then collision security is about 128 bits (i.e., it costs about 2^{128} operations to find a collision).
If n = 256, then preimage security is about 128 bits.
When passwords are stored as hashes, an attacker who steals the database can often do offline guessing (verify guesses without interacting with the system).
To slow down offline guessing, it is useful to use a deliberately slow password hashing function (e.g., bcrypt/Argon2), rather than a fast general-purpose hash.
A per-user salt should be unique, but it does not need to be secret.
A salt primarily exists to make computing the hash faster.
If the database stores a single unsalted hash per user, then an attacker can guess one password and check it against all users at once.

entry.title: Hash chaining
entry.item_body: Hash chaining can give tamper evidence, but it does not automatically provide authenticity. Check all statements that are true.

choices.item_body: Hash chaining can make tampering evident: if one block is changed, the hash links of all following blocks change too.
Hash chaining by itself does not tell you who created the data; for that you typically need something like digital signatures or a MAC.
If you publish only the hash of the latest block, then later you can detect if any earlier block was changed (because the chain would no longer match).
If the hash of the latest block is published (anchored) and blocks are hash-chained, then an attacker cannot delete an earlier block without detection (the recomputed tip hash will differ).

entry.title: Hash functions
entry.item_body: Proof-of-work (PoW) uses hash functions, but it relies on a different security property than collision resistance. Check all statements that are true.

choices.item_body: In PoW, miners typically do brute-force search over nonces until the hash output satisfies a target condition.
Finding such a nonce is mainly a preimage-style problem (unstructured search), not a collision-finding problem.

If collision resistance were broken, the PoW searching-for-a-nonce step would still be a preimage-style brute-force search, but other security goals of the chain could break (e.g., rewriting history could become easier).
Collision resistance is still useful in block chains for other reasons (e.g., to prevent an attacker from replacing old content with different content that has the same hash).
